Thomas, this is a great question that highlights an important area for 
fur=
ther research.  We can speculate on the right approach in this case 
(and I=
 have my hunches) but we won't know until we do some experiments 
and try i=
deas out.

To give some of my thoughts, perhaps the most obvious thing is s=
imilar 
to what you suggest:  Have two separate input sets, one for the "ty=
pe A 
info" and one for "type B info."  

The way this would look is e.g. i=
f A was 2D and B was 2D then the CPPN 
would have 4 inputs, 2 represent A s=
ource nodes and 2 representing B 
soource nodes.

Then, I would still have =
only one set of outputs.  I am still a little 
unclear on why you say the o=
utputs are from the second substrate?  In 
my understanding, this is still =
all one substrate, it's just that it 
collects inputs from two different so=
urces.  But it can still exist 
with only one set of outputs.  So if the ou=
tputs are 2D, the CPPN would 
have 2 more inputs representing the output ar=
ea for a total of 6 inputs 
(and one output representing the weight of a co=
nnection in the 
substrate).

If there was a hidden layer you could have it=
 exist in either the same 
geometry as A, the same geometry as B, or the sa=
me geometry as the 
outputs.  (For example by introducing a z dimension to =
any of these)  
Or you could have each kind of hidden layer all at once.

O=
f course, as you note, there are a lot of ways to do something like 
this. =
 I think it will be a great issue to explore, but it may require 
starting =
with a very simple domain that isolates the issue (i.e. 
orthogonal input t=
ypes) so we can concentrate on that rather than on a 
specific domain with =
its own complications.

One other issue to note is that even if two sets of=
 inputs are in 
effect unrelated, it may not necessarily hurt antyhing to p=
ut them in 
the same geometry.  For example, they could be two separate pla=
nes in 
the same cube.  On the face of it, it seems like that could cause 
=
problems, but we don't yet know whether the situation is that difficult 
to=
 deal with in practice.  There could also be hidden relationships 
that are=
 not obvious but still exploitable in a surprising way.

ken

> Hype=
rNEAT folks,

represent 
concepts
> that are not geometrically related? For instance, con=
sider something 
like a
> poker game where we want to input both players' a=
ctions and the cards 
we
> see. We might be able to come up with geometric =
encodings for either 
of
> these individually, but there's no obvious spaci=
al relationship 
between
> cards and actions.
